Class GameValue

  • java.lang.Object
    • GameValue
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable
    public class GameValue
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable
    Represents the value of a particular position in a game. In the context of Amazons, each GameValue stores a list of move options for both black and white, left and right respectively, for a given Board object.
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

        Removes all the GameValue objects stored deeper than the left and right lists of "this" GameValue object

      • equals

        public boolean equals​(GameValue game)
        Checking the equality of "this" GameValue, with another. This relates to the toString() content of both, and accepts lists on the left and right side which are not in the same order. The Moves stored also don't matter.
        Parameters:
        game - GameValue object to compare "this" object with
        Returns:
        true if both GameValue objects are the same, false otherwise

      • findPosition

        public int findPosition​(java.util.ArrayList<GameValue> gameValues,
                        java.lang.String value)
        Finding the position of a GameValue string representation, in a list of GameValue objects. Helper method for toString()
        Parameters:
        gameValues - list of GameValues to search
        value - GameValue string
        Returns:
        index of GameValue, or -1 of not found in list

      • maxDepth

        public int maxDepth​(java.lang.String side,
                    GameValue game)
        Finding the maximum recursive depth of possible moves, for a given side. Algorithm adapted from: https://www.educative.io/edpresso/finding-the-maximum-depth-of-a-binary-tree
        Parameters:
        side - Side to search
        game -
        Returns:
        Maximum depth for the side chosen

      • getSimplestForm

        public double getSimplestForm​(double a,
                              double b)
        Returns the simplest number that fits, according to the "Simplicity Rule" from chapter 2 of 'Winning Ways". For options < A, B, C | D, E, F>, x fits if its - Strictly greater than each of A, B, C - Strictly less than each of D, E, F - and x will be the "simplest" number that fits, if none of its options fit.
        Parameters:
        a - Numerical representation of left
        b - Numerical representation of right
        Returns:
        "Simplest" value that fits

      • isNumeric

        public static boolean isNumeric​(java.lang.String strNum)
        Checks if a string contains a number.
        Parameters:
        strNum - String to check
        Returns:
        true if string is numeric, false otherwise

      • isSimpleFraction

        public static boolean isSimpleFraction​(double left,
                                       double right)
        Checking if the difference between the left and right sides of a GameValue represent a "simple" fraction.
        Parameters:
        left - Numerical representation of left side
        right - Numerical representation of right side
        Returns:
        true if GameValue is a simple fraction, false otherwise

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Getting the human-readable form of "this" GameValue object. Using the same notation as "Winning Ways". Positive Values indicate a number of moves for left (black). Negative Values indicate a number of moves for right (white). Special notations include: * = < 0 | 0 > -n* = < -n | -n > Â± n = < n | -n >
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        String form of "this" GameValue

      • lessThanOrEqualTo

        public boolean lessThanOrEqualTo​(GameValue x,
                                 GameValue y)
        Given 2 GameValue Objects, X & Y, returns true if X <= Y, according to the definition in "Winning Ways": G >= H means that G + (-H) >= 0 or X <= Y unless some Y <= XL or some YR <= X
        Parameters:
        x - First GameValue object
        y - Second GameValue object
        Returns:
        true if X <= Y, false otherwise

      • getOutcomeClass

        public java.lang.String getOutcomeClass()
        Returns the outcome class for "this" GameValue object, meaning which player has a winning strategy.
        Returns:
        "First", "Second", "Left" or "Right"

      • compare

        public java.lang.String compare​(GameValue x,
                                GameValue y)
        Comparing 2 GameValue objects, checking which one is better for left
        Parameters:
        x - First GameValue object
        y - Second GameValue object
        Returns:
        "x", "y", "Equal", or "Fuzzy" if not clear

      • findMax

        public GameValue findMax​(java.util.ArrayList<GameValue> games,
                         java.lang.String side)
        Find the GameValue which dominates the most in a list
        Parameters:
        games - List to check through
        side - Which side we are using, "left" or "right"
        Returns:
        "Maximum" GameValue in list

      • findDuplicates

        public java.util.ArrayList<GameValue> findDuplicates​(java.util.ArrayList<GameValue> gameValues)
        Finding all duplicate GameValues, in a list of GameValue objects
        Parameters:
        gameValues - list of GameValues to search
        Returns:
        A list of the duplicate GameValues

      • simplify

        public void simplify()
        Simplifies "this" GameValue object, by first removing all GameValues that are dominated by others, before also removing duplicates GameValues. e.g. < A, B, C | D, E, F >, if A > B > C, removes B & C

      • plus

        public GameValue plus​(GameValue x,
                      GameValue y)
        Addition of 2 GameValue objects, using definition from "Winning Ways": X + Y = < XL + Y, X + YL | XR + Y, X + YR >
        Parameters:
        x - First GameValue object
        y - Second GameValue object
        Returns:
        Sum of first and second GameValue objects
